flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • Plano Model 3640-1 Tackle Bok
Tools
  • Caulking Gun, Waterproof Silicone
  • Dremel, Flexible Shaft, Metal Cutting bit
  • Scissors
  • Waterproof Silicone
  • pocketknife

lines.text: Pelican makes a variety of waterproof hard-shell cases, however they are expensive, and quite heavy, and are overkill for many purposes.  I am gearing up to do some backpacking, and so need to have somewhere to hold some electronics where they will be immune to the elements.  This project builds such a waterproof case from an inexpensive fishing-lure tackle-box, modified with materials on-hand.
lines.text_raw: Pelican makes a variety of waterproof hard-shell cases, however they are expensive, and quite heavy, and are overkill for many purposes.  I am gearing up to do some backpacking, and so need to have somewhere to hold some electronics where they will be immune to the elements.  This project builds such a waterproof case from an inexpensive fishing-lure tackle-box, modified with materials on-hand.

lines.text: The tackle-box listed in the parts list retails for $8.99 at Canadian Tire.  Apparently I got ripped off as one angler's review lists its cost at $4.00 USD.  Canadian Tire's bench-vice prices are even worse.  You may substitute the case of your choice and adapt these instructions accordingly.
lines.text_raw: The tackle-box listed in the parts list retails for $8.99 at Canadian Tire.  Apparently I got ripped off as one angler's review lists its cost at $4.00 USD.  Canadian Tire's bench-vice prices are even worse.  You may substitute the case of your choice and adapt these instructions accordingly.

lines.text: Perhaps I should have inspected the item more closely before I bought it, as when opened, there are some dividers molded with the case.  These need to be removed.
lines.text_raw: Perhaps I should have inspected the item more closely before I bought it, as when opened, there are some dividers molded with the case.  These need to be removed.

lines.text: Using a dremel with a small dental drilling tool, or a metal cutter (not shown) use the lowest speed and cut out those annoying dividers close to the attached surface.  Be careful you do not puncture the case or you will have to weld some extra plastic overtop that place.  I would use a butane-powered soldering iron on its lowest setting for that.
lines.text_raw: Using a dremel with a small dental drilling tool, or a metal cutter (not shown) use the lowest speed and cut out those annoying dividers close to the attached surface.  Be careful you do not puncture the case or you will have to weld some extra plastic overtop that place.  I would use a butane-powered soldering iron on its lowest setting for that.

lines.text: Once most of the offending plastic is removed, make a second pass to even things out.
lines.text_raw: Once most of the offending plastic is removed, make a second pass to even things out.

lines.text: On the top lid, I left ribs about 4mm high to provide some resistance to squeezing pressures while the box is in my backpack.  Reinforcing will be added as a last step to augment this.
lines.text_raw: On the top lid, I left ribs about 4mm high to provide some resistance to squeezing pressures while the box is in my backpack.  Reinforcing will be added as a last step to augment this.

lines.text: Use a pocket knife to trim away the little bits of plastic that remain attached to the box by thin filaments, which are largely unavoidable when working this kind of material.
lines.text_raw: Use a pocket knife to trim away the little bits of plastic that remain attached to the box by thin filaments, which are largely unavoidable when working this kind of material.

lines.text: Thoroughly clean any remaining debris, paying close attention to the Si gasket groove.  Use compressed air if it is available.  I used a dirty toothbrush, contaminated by a small quantity of machine oil.  Oops.
lines.text_raw: Thoroughly clean any remaining debris, paying close attention to the Si gasket groove.  Use compressed air if it is available.  I used a dirty toothbrush, contaminated by a small quantity of machine oil.  Oops.

lines.text: The supplied Silicone gasket fits loosely in its groove.   Apply a bead of Silicone caulking to the grove and then fit the gasket.  Press it into place firmly, and wipe away any exces.
lines.text_raw: The supplied Silicone gasket fits loosely in its groove.   Apply a bead of Silicone caulking to the grove and then fit the gasket.  Press it into place firmly, and wipe away any exces.

lines.text: Curing times will be extended since the silicone caulking is exposed to air only at the edges of the gasket.  I waited for 24 hours before closing the box and engaging the clasps.
lines.text_raw: Curing times will be extended since the silicone caulking is exposed to air only at the edges of the gasket.  I waited for 24 hours before closing the box and engaging the clasps.

lines.text: Pad the top and bottom interior surfaces with compressible foam, cutting to shape with scissors, and fixed in place with glue.
lines.text_raw: Pad the top and bottom interior surfaces with compressible foam, cutting to shape with scissors, and fixed in place with glue.

lines.text: In retrospect, I should have used aerosol adhesive.  The hot-glue looks unsightly when viewed from the outside.  Live and learn.
lines.text_raw: In retrospect, I should have used aerosol adhesive.  The hot-glue looks unsightly when viewed from the outside.  Live and learn.

lines.text: Finally, use two or more of the supplied inserts to support the upper and lower case-halves, positioned to the sizes of the gear you will store in the box.
lines.text_raw: Finally, use two or more of the supplied inserts to support the upper and lower case-halves, positioned to the sizes of the gear you will store in the box.

lines.text: I just happened to have a section of 1/8" x 1 1/2" Aluminium bar stock on hand and cut a section as shown, bent to shape.  Totally overkill, but in a pinch the piece may be used to fashion arrow-heads or whatever bits that you might need in a survival situation.
lines.text_raw: I just happened to have a section of 1/8" x 1 1/2" Aluminium bar stock on hand and cut a section as shown, bent to shape.  Totally overkill, but in a pinch the piece may be used to fashion arrow-heads or whatever bits that you might need in a survival situation.

lines.text: The last step involves testing the box to certify that it is, indeed, waterproof.  As manufactured, this box is only water-resistant, and cannot handle full immersion.
lines.text_raw: The last step involves testing the box to certify that it is, indeed, waterproof.  As manufactured, this box is only water-resistant, and cannot handle full immersion.

lines.text: I used my batth-tub as I did not have a bucket large enough on-hand.  A hot-tub, swimming pool, or lake may be substituted if you have one available.
lines.text_raw: I used my batth-tub as I did not have a bucket large enough on-hand.  A hot-tub, swimming pool, or lake may be substituted if you have one available.

lines.text: Leakage should be easy to detect, but a square of paper-towel inserted before testing may make finding seepage a little easier.
lines.text_raw: Leakage should be easy to detect, but a square of paper-towel inserted before testing may make finding seepage a little easier.

lines.text: If the box passes, your waterproof box is ready for use.  As a precaution, put your delicate electronics in good-quality zip-lock bags.  They, too may be handy while you're out in the backwoods.
lines.text_raw: If the box passes, your waterproof box is ready for use.  As a precaution, put your delicate electronics in good-quality zip-lock bags.  They, too may be handy while you're out in the backwoods.

lines.text: I would recommend testing the watertight integrity of the box before each camping excursion as a means of verifying that it will in fact keep your toys, lighters, matches, etc. dry.
lines.text_raw: I would recommend testing the watertight integrity of the box before each camping excursion as a means of verifying that it will in fact keep your toys, lighters, matches, etc. dry.

guide.summary: Pelican cases are very expensive; a waterproof fishing tackle box can be substituted after making very minor modifications.
guide.title: Inexpensive waterproof plastic case.

tools.text: Dremel, Flexible Shaft, Metal Cutting bit
